Tony Alesi }} '''The Four Aces''' is an [[United States|American]] male [[traditional pop music]] quartet, popular since the 1950s. Over the last half-century, the group amassed many [[music recording sales certification|gold records]]. Its million-selling signature tunes include "[[Love Is a Many-Splendored Thing (song)|Love is a Many-Splendored Thing]]",{{cite book | first= Joseph | last= Murrells | year= 1978 | title= The Book of Golden Discs | edition= 2nd | publisher= Barrie and Jenkins Ltd | location= London | page= 73 | isbn= 0-214-20512-6}} "[[Three Coins in the Fountain (song)|Three Coins in the Fountain]]",{{cite book | first= Joseph | last= Murrells | year= 1978 | title= The Book of Golden Discs | edition= 2nd | publisher= Barrie and Jenkins Ltd | location= London | page= 68 | isbn= 0-214-20512-6}} "[[Stranger in Paradise (song)|Stranger in Paradise]]", "[[Tell Me Why (1951 song)|Tell Me Why]]",{{cite book | first= Joseph | last= Murrells | year= 1978 | title= The Book of Golden Discs | edition= 2nd | publisher= Barrie and Jenkins Ltd | location= London | page= 55 | isbn= 0-214-20512-6}} and "[[(It's No) Sin]]". Other big sellers included "[[Shangri-La (1946 song)|Shangri-La]]", "[[Perfidia]]", and "[[Sincerely (song)|Sincerely]]". The original members, responsible for every song made popular by the group, included [[Al Alberts]], Dave Mahoney, Lou Silvestri, and Rosario "Sod" Vaccaro.{{Cite web | title = The Four Aces - Inductees - The Vocal Group Hall of Fame Foundation | publisher = The Vocal Group Hall of Fame Foundation | url = http://www.vocalgroup.org/inductees/the_four_aces.html | accessdate = 2010-09-11}} ==Career== Alberts went to South [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania|Philadelphia]] High School and [[Temple University]], and served in the [[United States Navy]], where he met Mahoney. Originally, Alberts sang with Mahoney playing behind him, and later they added Vaccaro on trumpet and Silvestri on drums. They played locally in the Philadelphia area, and Alberts started his own record label, [[Victoria Records (1952)|Victoria Records]], when they could not find a distributor to release their first record, "[[(It's No) Sin]]". It sold a million copies, and [[Decca Records]] soon signed the group, billing them as The Four Aces featuring Al Alberts. Alberts left the group in 1958 to try to make it as a soloist, but never made the charts. He was replaced as lead singer by Fred Diodati, who had attended South Philadelphia High School a few years after Alberts. After Alberts had left the group, Mahoney and Vaccaro also left. Silvestri never left the group, but led three new members: Diodati, Tony Alesi, and Joe Giglio. The Original Aces later asked Silvestri to rejoin the original group, and he did. It was then that Diodati led a new line-up, which consisted of Diodati, Alesi, Giglio, and Harry Heisler. After almost 19 years with the group, Alesi developed a medical condition that forced him to leave the group. {{As of|2013}} the Four Aces members are Diodati, Giglio, Heisler, and Danny Colingo. These members sing all the songs the original Four Aces had made popular at one time. In 1975, Diodati, Alesi, Giglio, and Heisler were awarded the right to the name in a court suit in which the original members tried to re-establish their right. The court allowed the founding members to tour as "The Original Four Aces, Featuring Al Alberts", which they did, finally retiring the act in 1987. Diodati, Giglio, Heisler, and Colingo continue to legally use the name of the Four Aces and perform the songs made popular by the Original Four Aces. The founding lead singer, Alberts, died of [[Death by natural causes|natural causes]] on November 27, 2009 at age 87.[http://www.thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2009b.html Thedeadrockstarsclub.com] - accessed April 2011 Mahoney died on July 12, 2012 of complications from Alzheimer's Disease at age 86.{{cite web|last=Naedele|first=Walter|title=David A. Mahoney, 86, 1950s singer was one of Four Aces|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/obituaries/20120711_David_A__Mahoney__86__1950s_singer_as_one_of_Four_Aces.html|publisher=Philadelphia Media Network|accessdate=25 July 2012}} Silvestri died on January 27, 2013 at age 86.[http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/delcotimes/obituary.aspx?pid=162731860 Legacy.com Obituaries] Vaccaro died on April 5, 2013 at age 90.{{cite web|title=Rosario Vaccaro Obituary|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/delcotimes/obituary.aspx?n=rosario-vaccaro&pid=164150612|work=RememberingPa.us|publisher=Legacy.com|accessdate=April 10, 2013}} ==Awards and recognition== The Four Aces were inducted into the [[Vocal Group Hall of Fame]] in 2001. They vocalized not only the lyrics, but all instrumental parts of their music, recording on the Decca label in the UK. http://www.45worlds.com/78rpm/record/f5198 In 1948–49, [[Bill Haley]] fronted a group called the Four Aces of Western Swing – often referred to as simply The Four Aces.
